Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back with only details of clypeus and undercut at front of scarab surviving, rest rubbed smooth; at side, legs much worn, though still indicated with undercut triangle, suggesting originally a well modelled piece; underside bearing incised hieroglyphic inscription arranged vertically; pierced lengthways; glaze lost; pale yellow core; very much worn.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The drawing in Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII no. 31 already indicated that this scarab was badly worn (with cross-hatching over the motif). Scarabs and scaraboids in glazed composition and Egyptian blue were produced in large quantity in the 'Scarab Factory' where this piece was found, before being exported in the whole Mediterranean area (on the various productions of the Scarab Factory, see: Gorton 1996, 91-131; Webb forthcoming). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gardner 1888 / Naukratis II (pl. XVIII, no. 31) (indicated as much worn in original publication)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.129) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol
